abstract.text: Results ef the investication of cold nucicar fusion on palladium are reporied both for electrolysis of heavy water D:O and a muture D,O+H.O ( \\\l and for palladium uturaled with deuienum gaa. The eaustence of ths phenomenon was cuamined by deotion of neutrons and gamma-quanta from the resctions d+d--'He+ 3.27 MeV, p+d--Hety (S.S MeV ),and by measaring the characteristie X-ray radiation of palladium due to the effect of charged products He. p. t. The upper limits of the d-d and pd fusion (partial) reaction ratcs arc given by d+d-'Hetn, dr 1.2x 10-*s- , d+ p--He +y.Ar6 2.4x 10 :- (both ebectrol-ysis); d +d--'He+n,A;<6x10-3;-! (gasoous phase).

body_text.text: Recently (March-April 1989) articles in the popular press and scientific publications have reported the experimental observation of cold nuclear fusion on a palladium cathode in the process of heavy water (D-O) electrolysis. According to refs. [1.2], it was proved by the following experimental observations.
(1) A 3- to 4-fold excess of the counting rate of neutrons produced in the reaction
over the background level

(2） Detection of 2.2 MeV gamma-quanta by a Nal(Tl) scintillation detector, according to the inierpretation of the authors of ref. [1]. they resulted from interaction of neutrons from reaction $( 1 )$ with water (H:O) used for cooling the electrolyzer
(3) A higher content of tritium produced via the fuson channel
in D.O. According to the estimation of the authors of ref. [1) the tritium production rate was 10* atoms/s.
(4) A large excess of the power released in the electrolyzer over the power applied to it.
These reports encouraged us to investigate the phenomcnon, and we report below the results of the experiments searching for the products of reactions (1),(2).
We have carried out two series of experiments: with heavy water clectrolysis and with saturation of Pd with deuterium gas.
Fig. I shows the experimental lay-out for the whole cycle of investigations.

To detect fusion neutrons, two SNM-14 boron-containing detectors were used. The electrolyzer and the neutron dctectors were placed into a polyethyi-ene retarder shielded with borated polyethylene against background neutron radiations. The thickness of the polyethyiene between the neutron counter and the clectrolyzer was $- 1 5$ cm, that is, quite enough for thermalization of neutrons not only from reaction (1) but also from the 32Cf and (Pu+ Be) sources. The neutron detection cfficicncy was experimentally determined with 3Cf and (Pu+Be) calibraled sources; it was measured to be 0.32%.

In the first series of expcriments we carried out clectrolysus of heavy water D-O (99.80% pure) and a mixture D,O+H.O (I:l ). The clectrolyzcr is schematically shown in fig. 2 Chemically pure Pd was used as a cathode and platinum as an anode. The cathode was a hollow cyinder 30 mm in diameter,. 42 mm high, with I mm thick walls (volume 4 cm'). The Pd-cathode was placed between two net cylinder-shaped platinum anodes. The amount of D.O in the electrolyzer was 160 cm'.

In different 50 h exposures the current density varied from 1 to 125 mA/cm'. In exposures with high currents the conductance in D;0 was increased by adding Na.CO, soda ash in concentrations from 5x10-'to 1.9x10-' M. The maximal current was 5 A. The obtained results are given in table l.
From these results it follows that if cold nuclear fusion exists, then the yicld of neutrons produced in reaction (1) is less than
From theoretical considerations [3,4] it follows that the probability of the renction

In vicw of this, clcctrolysis of the mixture D.O(50%)+H,O(50%) was carried out in the same electrolyrer. To identify process (4) a Gc(Li)-de-tector 100 cm* in volume was used to dctect 5.5 MeV gamma-quanta. An analysis of the gamma-spectra measured during 64 h gave no evidence of the effect. The intensity of the process was found to be less than

In addition, during the electrolysis experiments we measured the X-ray radhation caused by interaction of charged products of reactions $( 1 )$ and (3) with Pd atoms. To detect the X-ray radiation, a l cmi HPGe-dctector was used.
Fig. 3 shows an X-ray spectrum obtained in the exposure with the electrolyzer switched on. The measured spectrum did not differ from the background one - no KX-ray radiation of Pd was found.

In the second series of cxperiments Pd was satu-raled with deuterium gas. First, a vacuum-thermal treatment of Pd was carried out by heating it to 750" $c$ at the residual gas pressure 5 x 10-* mbar. Fig. 4 shows the relevant experimental lay-out.
Saturation of Pd (-290 g) with deuterium was carried out at a pressure of 1-2 atm for about 3 h and resulted in palladium deuteride Pd $\\\mathbf{D}_{0},$ Detection of

the fusion neutrons took place both during the saturation process and after it. No statistically significant difference was found in the results. Then the measurements were carmed out at 250*C (in this case the deuterium pressure in the system was 20 atm). The results obtained are gaven in tabie 2.
As known, the basic experiments were carried out with heavy water electrolysis, ie. in a system with

electric current. A possible effect of the current taken into accoun $\\\mathbf{\\\omega}$ an "equivalent" experiment was carried out with deuterium gas. A current up to 9 A was applied to palladium (130 g) saturated with deuterium and piaced in the deuterium atmosphere. Saturation of palladium with deuicrium took place at room temperature at a deuterium pressure excess of $1-2$ atm. The end of saturation was marked by the end of the deuterium pressure drop. The current was 4-9 $\\\mathbf{A}$ Le. of the same order as in the D,O ciec-trolysis experiment $( I_{\\\mathrm{max}}=S \\\mathrm{ A )}$ . The results obtained are gaven in table 3.
From tables 2 and 3 it follows that the ncutron yicld is less than 10-* n/s cm? Pd at 95% confidence level.

On the basis of the valucs obtained for $\\\varrho$ and $e,$ one can estimate the rates of nuclear reactions (1) $\\\mathbf{s}^{-1}$ 10d6413523263009252105 国d热品52区0m $s^{-1}$

in the experiments with deuterium gas. Our estimations of $\\\vdots$ are in good agreement with the results of ref. [S] which involved ncutron detectors of another type. With an effect like this, a detailed consideration of all possible backpround sources is nec-esary. Besides the evident background sources, such as cosmic radiation, operating nuccar-physies machines (accclerators, reactors) we shall touch upon some non-trivial sitwations. For example, the heavy water itself used in experiment is a neutron source due to the effect of gamma-quanta with energy over 2.23 MeV (photodisintegration of the deuteron). Besides vanious kinds of technical contamination, natural radioactive isotopes, which are present in building materials, can be a source of these quanta.

Our quantitative estamination of this background was based on the tabulated data and on the results of the background gamma-radiaton measurement in the laboratory. In our laboralory the intensity of the 3o*Tl y-linc (E=2.614 MeV) in the background spectrum is 3 y/s for 160 cm* of D,O in the elec-trolyzer. This gamma-radiation intensity corresponds to a photoncutron yield of 5x 10-* n/s, calculated for a cross section of 1 mbarn and a detector efficiency of 0.3%. As seen, if one takes into account possible lurge fluctuations of the natural radionuclide content in building materiais, the above estimations confirm the necessity of correct determination of the background.

There is another possible neutron background source: the $( {\ f a}, {\ f n} )$ -type reactions on carbon and oxygen initiat -particles emited by radon and its decay products that are present in the air.
According to estimations, under our conditions the neutron background is 10-5 n/s, the concentration of natural radionuclides in the air being 10-'` Ci/R.

In ref. (1] the channel of reaction (3) was iden-tifned by accumulation of tritium in the clectrolyte. In this case lithium salts must not be used as an electrolyte added to water to increase conductance. Cosmic neutrons initiate the tritium-producing (n, $\\\omega$ rceaction on "Li nucici. Besides, old lithium salts may contain noticeable amounts of tritium accumulated during the storage time. Regular calibration of neutron detectors by means of neutron sources speeds up tritium production. If these facts are ignored, the results can be distorted significantly.

The above considerations allow us to make the following conclusion. If cold nuclear fusion really occurs under the conditions existing dunng our investigations, its probability, nevertheless, is extremety small and it can hardly be a power source in the near future.

back_matter.text: The authors cxpress their gratitude to Profesor Is. Vylov, Durector of the Laboraiory of Nucicar Problems in JINR. for his support and constant interest in the work, to V.B. Belyaev, S.M. Koren-chenko, B.S. Nepanov and A.N. Perevezenisev for uscful discussions.
